advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...<

computer.colors: 16 (each color can have 8 luminances) = 128 colors maximum in the lowest graphic mode (requiring display list interruption to have them simultaneously)and up to 256 colors in some specific modes for machines having the GTIA chip instead of the CTIA
computer.coprocessor: ANTIC (Scrolling, Sprites, Video), CTIA / GTIA (Color, Sprites, Collisions), POKEY (timers, sound, keyboard, serial I/O), PIA 6810 (I/O, including the 4 joystick ports)
computer.description:
The Atari 400 and 800 were the first home computers to use custom coprocessors and the first to use "sprites" and special video interruptions like display lists; features that would be implemented later on the Commodore 64, then on the Commodore Amiga (Atari 400/800 and Amiga were both designed by Jay Miner).
It offered high graphic resolution, lots of colors and great sound capabilities, more than other computers could do then! The two models had same characteristics, but the 800 had 48 KB of RAM (instead of 16 kb), two cartridge ports (only one for the 400) and a proper mechanical keyboard (a membrane keyboard for the 400).
In fact the very first Atari 800 Computers were shipped with 8 or 16 KB memory, expandable to 48 KB. After initial release, the 800 came standard with 48 KB memory.
Prior to production, the 800 was known inside Atari as code name "Colleen". It is rumored that Colleen and Candy (the 400 code name) were actually secretaries at Atari.

emulator.description: Atari 800, 800XL, 130XE and 5200 emulator for Unix, Amiga, MS-DOS, Atari TT/Falcon, SDL and WinCE

Percom disc drive|||Advert|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;PERCOM DISC DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;Advert</strong><br><blockquote>March 1983 Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The Percom Data AT-88 offers 88 Kbytes (formatted) in single-density, with plug-in ease of attachment to your Atari. The AT-88 has integral power supply, "no-patch" to Atari DOS and critical constant speed regulation.<br> Take advantage of this low introductory price of $488... </font> <

Corvus Systems hard-drive|||10Mb hard-drive|||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;CORVUS SYSTEMS HARD-DRIVE</strong></font><br><strong>&gt;&nbsp;10Mb hard-drive</strong><br><blockquote>This is a 10Mb hard-drive. With up to 8 multiplexers with 8 ports each it's possible to connect up to 64 Atari 800's up to a single 10 or even 20 megabyte Atari system. Still in use Today at the Fordham Prepatory School in the Bronx, NY is a 64 Atari 800 computer network hooked up to a single Corvus Hard drive system ! <br><br> The Corvus hard disk system also sported a unique and innovative back-up system called "The Corvus Mirror" which was a VCR interface system that allowed you to plug a standard Video Cassette Recorder (VCR) up to the Corvus Hard Drive System to save back-ups of the hard disk onto actual Video Tapes!!!<

Atari 830 Acoustic coupler||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI 830 ACOUSTIC COUPLER</strong></font><br><blockquote>User had to place the handset of his phone into the "cups" on the modem.<br> This type of modem wasn't very reliable as it picked up surround noise and randomly disconnect the communication session<br><br> Features:<br> - Up to 300 bits per second<br> - Bell 103/113 modem compatible<br> - requires Atari 850 Interface Module <

Touch Tablet||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;TOUCH TABLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>The touch tablet was the best tool for drawing and painting. It shipped with the AtariArtist cartridge.<

ATARI 825 printer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ATARI 825 PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Atari 825 printer was a rebadged version of the 80-column Centronics 727 dot-matrix printer. As it was a parallel printer, it required the Atari 850 Interface. It was able to print all the Atari ASCII character set at 50 characters per second. <

computer.keyboard: QWERTY full Stroke keyboard, 62 keys4 function keys (Reset, Option, Select, Start)
computer.ports: Monitor RGB output, RF TV video output, 2 cartridge slots, Atari Serial Input/Ouput (SIO) port, 4 controller jacks, 4 internal slots for memory modules
computer.ram: 8 KB to 48 KB (with memory expansion boards)

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;MOTHERBOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mother board is only populated with passive and input/output components. The 'active' daughter cards are inserted into the five slots. Notice the impressive number of resistances perfectly aligned. <br><br> <b>(1)</b> 2 ROM cartridge slots. This is where the Basic language cartridge is inserted.<br> <b>(2)</b> The 'main' card (Microprocessor and specialized components) is inserted here.<br> <b>(3)</b> ROM card slot. <br> <b>(4)</b> Each of these 3 connectors can receive a 16 Kb RAM card. <br> <b>(5)</b> Switch cutting off the power supply when the cartridge lid is raised. <br> <b>(6)</b> Composite video output connector (B&W monitor). <br> <b>(7)</b> D.C. power regulation components. <br> <b>(8)</b> T.V. channel selector. <br> <b>(9)</b> Power supply input, provided by an external transformer. <br> <b>(10)</b> On/Off switch. <br> <b>(11)</b> Serial connector. <br> <b>(12)</b> RGB video connector.<br> <b>(13)</b> Keyboard 'OPTION' key. <br> <b>(14)</b> Keyboard 'SELECT' key. <br> <b>(15)</b> Keyboard 'START' key. <br> <b>(16)</b> Power leds. <br> <b>(17)</b> Keyboard 'SYSTEM RESET' key. <br> <b>(18)</b> Keyboard connector. <br> <b>(19)</b> Four joystick sockets. <br> <b>(20</b> Loudspeaker. <br> <b>(21)</b> PIA circuit (Peripheral Interface Adapter) which handles the 4 joysticks. <br> <b>(22)</b> Specialized Component called ' POKEY', in charge of the keyboard, inputs/outputs, components synchronization and sound. <br> <b>(23)</b> System clock circuit (frequency generator).<

<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;DAUGHTERS CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>These five daughter cards form the main part of the system. They are plugged into the five mother board connectors intended for this purpose <br><br> <b>(1)</b> This specialized circuit called CTIA or GTIA handle colors, graphics layers and some inputs/outputs. <br> <b>(2)</b> These ROM circuits can be replaced with others containing other languages or software. <br> <b>(3)</b> The Atari 800 can receive up to 3 x 16 Kb memory boards. <br> <b>(4)</b> Color adjustment potentiometer. <br> <b>(5)</b> MOS 6502 microprocessor. <br> <b>(6)</b> Two quartz hidden into this grey metal box, are used to synchronize the microprocessor and video. <br> <b>(7)</b> Specialized circuit (there are 3 specialized circuits in the Atari 800) handling the graphic scrollings.<
